physDesc.p: Eleven pieces bound together, written probably in Austria, in the 13th–14th (items J, K), and 15th cents.

supportDesc.extent:
i+192 leaves (fol. i, left blank, is part of the first quire)
206 140

binding.p: 15th-cent. monastic binding of wooden boards covered with white leather (probably polished sheepskin) decorated with tooled panels and stamps; sewing strengthened in the middle of the quires with strips of parchment taken from MSS.; traces of a label on the upper cover.

history.provenance: Formerly no. 596 in the library of Admont (see paper label on spine).
Sold by Admont in or after 1934 to L. and A. Brecher of Brünn; see G. Moser-Mersky, Mittelalt. Bibl.kat. Österreichs iii, 1961, p. 9.
Bought by Lyell from Davis and Orioli in April 1938; see their Cat. 79 (Nov. 1937), no. 90.
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.

recordHist.source: Description adapted from A. de la Mare, Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts Bequeathed to the Bodleian Library Oxford by James P. R. Lyell (1971); with additions by Andrew Dunning. Catalogue, p. 137 Catalogue, p. 138 Catalogue, p. 139 Catalogue, p. 140 Catalogue, p. 141 Catalogue, p. 142 Catalogue, p. 143

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: A. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts in Oxford Libraries (1984), no. 639 (fols. 1-24)

msItem.author: Jean Gerson
msItem.title: Opusculum tripartitum
msItem.rubric: (fol. 1r) Incipit opusculum tripertitum Iohannis de Gersona de preceptis, de confessione et de sciencia moriendi
msItem.incipit: Cristianitati suus qualiscunque zelator
msItem.explicit: (fol. 24r) laudabiliter observatur.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit opusculum tripertitum de preceptis, de confessione et de sciencia mortis per eximium theologie doctorem magistrum Iohannem de Gersona alme universitatis Parisiensis cancellarium compilatum. 1471.
msItem.bibl: Pr. L. E. du Pin, Joannis Gersonii Opera Omnia, Antwerp, 1706, 1, col. 427–50.

msItem.note: Fol. 24v is blank.

supportDesc.support: paper; watermark, steer’s head with cross and flower with seven petals, cf. Briquet nos. 14547, 14550–2

handDesc.handNote: Written in a current hybrid hand in 1471.

msItem.author: Jodocus Weiler of Heilbronn
msItem.title: Tractatus de usu et modo dictandi
msItem.rubric: (fol. 26r) Prima tabula in qua continentur salutaciones ad summum pontificem
msItem.incipit: Sanctissimo in Christo patri ac domino domino Ewgenio divina providencia sacrosancte Romane ac universalis ecclesie summo pontifici Sigismundus eadem providencia Romanorum imperator
msItem.explicit: (fol. 39v) Valete. Deus conducat vos et cum prosperitate reducat etc.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit tractatus de usu et modo dictandi editus per venerabilem magistrum Iodocum de Haylprunn waccalarium formatus in theologia.
msItem.note: Another MS. is cited by L. Rockinger, Briefsteller und Formelbücher, 1863, pp. 952–3 n. 2.

msItem.title: De exordiis
msItem.incipit: Quia melius ex forma quam ex materia rei formande habetur doctrina, idcirco de octo modis exordiendi duxi formulas
msItem.explicit: (fol. 44v) et promovendos etc et sic est finis Deo gracias etc.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit tractatulus de exordiis octo modorum Deo gracias.

msItem.note: Fols. 25–25v, 45–48v are blank.

supportDesc.support: paper; watermark, mount with cross and flower, cf. Briquet no. 11825

handDesc.handNote: Written in the 15th cent, in a cursive hand.

msItem.title: Notes on Aristotle, Ethics
msItem.rubric: (fol. 49r) Hic incipiuntur auctoritates primi libri ethicorum
msItem.incipit: Omnia bona appetunt / Cognicio finis utilis est in arte
msItem.explicit: (fol. 52r) (bk. 10) quia intellectus est principialissimum hominis

msItem.note: Fol. 52v–56v are blank.

handDesc.handNote: Written in the 15th cent, in a cursive hand

msItem.title: Treatise on dictamen
msItem.incipit: (fol. 57r) Rethorice dulcedinis florenti sermone
msItem.explicit: (fol. 85v) ad eterna celestium habitacula valeamus feliciter pervenire. Amen.

supportDesc.support: paper; watermarks very hard to see, mount in circle, scales, cf. Briquet nos. 11878, etc.(?), 2399

layoutDesc.layout: frame ruling in ink, 2 cols., c. 31–4 lines, 160 105

handDesc.handNote: Written in the 15th cent, in a cursive hand

msItem.author: Mauricius Leydis
msItem.title: Ars predicandi

msItem.incipit: Communicaturus caritative meis desiderantibus hoc quod de modo predicandi ad populos multos per labores donavit altissimus
msItem.explicit: (fol. 89r) descendunt quando per moralia se inferioribus (?) conformant

msItem.incipit: Ulterius notandum quod predicacionum alia de festis, alia de tempore

msItem.rubric: Declaracio. Declaracio paradigmatis de sanctis et primo de prima riga primi semicirculi
msItem.incipit: (fol. 89v) Fulgendus in sermone infra octavas Epiphanie
msItem.explicit: (fol. 100r) (de tempore) de figuris et propheciis etc. Et hec de paradigmate de tempore

msItem.rubric: Sequitur nunc de partibus integralibus sermonis
msItem.incipit: Expeditis duobus paradigmatibus quorum primum fuit de sanctis et secundum de tempore restat nunc dicere de partibus integralibus sermonis
msItem.explicit: (fol. 105r) hoc nobis prestare dignetur id est ipse cum patre et spiritu sancto Deus imus in secula benedictus Amen.

msItem.finalRubric: Explicit Ars predicandi per reverendissimum magistrum Mauririum Leydis per manus domini Nicolai Weigselpammer (?) de Wasserurga Anno domini Mºccccº et Lii in vigilia vigile Nativitatis Christi etc.

msItem.note: This is preceded (fol. 86v–88) by paradigms expounded in the text:

msItem.incipit: Beneficio impenso in ipsa festivitate

msItem.note: heading mostly cropped by binder
msItem.incipit: Sancti vita atque conversacione
msItem.note: See fol. 89–96v;
drawing with text
msItem.incipit: Utrobique nocet nos supersticionum perversitate
msItem.note: See fol. 96v–97v;
see fol. 97v–100. On fol. 87v are lists of different kinds of feast days.

See H. Caplan, Medieval Artes Praedicandi (Cornell Studies in Classical Philology, XXIV), 1934, no. 27; T. Charland, Artes Praedicandi (Publ. de l’Inst. d’études médiév. d’Ottawa, vii), 1936, p. 70, both of whom cite our MS. as Admont 596. Only the introduction is similar to the printed Aquinas tract cited by them (Hain 1351–62).

msItem.rubric: Sermo de visitacione virginis benedicte factus Radispone a fratre Iohannis de Capistrano doctore egregio iuris civilis ac viro devoto ordinis minorum
msItem.incipit: Ut audivit Elisabet salutacionem Marie exultavit infans … Cum enim virgo benedicta fuisset
msItem.explicit: (fol. 108v) maior aut par. Et sic patet (?) declaracio istarum prerogativarum virginis et aliarum prerogativarum declaracio obmittitur diligendus studiose etc.

msItem.note: Followed by a note on the celebration of the feast of the Visitation.
(top of heading cut off by binder)
In several parts:

msItem.incipit: Gegimina viperarum quis vobis demonstrabit … Genimina ostendit eos culpabiles
msItem.note: ends with a list of 50 sins arising from games

msItem.rubric: Item nota versus et metra de ludo
msItem.incipit: Et cum taxillis tabellis ludo tibi crimina fiunt
msItem.note: 7 lines. Cf. WIC 7487;

msItem.rubric: Nota alia metra de eiusdem Ovidius poeta dicta vit
msItem.incipit: Nunc etenim mihi pisces captare marinos
msItem.note: 38 lines. Probably also in Munich clm. 5844, which Walther cites for the previous item.

msItem.incipit: Primum peccatum et principale est superbia
msItem.explicit: (fol. 110r) quelibet vida orienda ex ludo per se ipsum explicare secundum statum specialem(?) per propriam industriam naturalem etc.
msItem.note: On these reports of sermons given at Regensburg, see L. Luszczki, De manuscriptis sermonum S. Ioannis de Capistrano, Antemurale 5 (1959), 127–9. The two sermons in our MS. seem to be from the same recension as the three in MS. Vienna 3693, fol. 122–8.
Fol. 110v is blank.
An incomplete version of the first of the four basic figures of Ramon Lull, given in his Ars brevis, followed by
(also incomplete)
with revolving discs
see F. Yates, The Art of Ramon Lull, Journal of Warburg and Courtauld Institutes 17 (1954), 116 and Pl. 8b, c, d, e;
a table, with the letters B–K at the left, (left to right)
msItem.incipit: Bonitas, Differenda, Utrum
msItem.note: The equivalent of the first three lines of Lull’s Alphabet (Yates, pl. 8a)
a list of Lull’s nine Dignitates Dei or Essencialis Accentualis
Definition of the absoluta and relata
msItem.incipit: B. Bonitas est ens racione cuius bonum agit bonum
msItem.note: similar to Lull’s Ars Brevis, cap. vi. De Diffinitionibus (in Opera, ed. Zetzner, Strassburg, 1617, p. 10)
Followed by definitions of Lull’s questiones (Utrum-Cum quo)
msItem.incipit: Utrum querit possibilitatem rei

msItem.note: Examples of the application of the Art using mensa and liber

msItem.incipit: Virtutes eius quis sufficit enarrare. Est enim mensa valde bona
msItem.note: etc., using the eighteen principles

msItem.incipit: Rethoricum formabitur ex novem questionibus et omnibus tripartitis sic Utrum mensa est
msItem.note: , etc., using the nine questiones

msItem.incipit: Item nota quot decem et octo principia supra dicta et eciam novem questiones supra dicta sunt generalia sive generales ad omne quod est et possunt applicari ad omnem rem et ad omne thema ut iam patuit superius de mensa. Exemplum secundum de libro et dicitur sic. Virtutes eius quis sufficit enarrare. Est liber valde bonus
Utrum librum est. Responditur quod sic
msItem.explicit: Cum quo tu es o homo certe cum gratia Dei si vis etc. Et sic de aliis.

msItem.note: Fol. 115v–121v are blank.

msItem.title: Ars memoratiua
msItem.note: (so called in a list of contents on fol. 86r)
msItem.incipit: Invoco auxilium altissimi creatoris ut ab illo summantur exordium medium et finis. Quantum ad principium huius artis est notandum quod ars ista consistit in duobus punctis, scilicet in locis et in maginibus
msItem.explicit: (fol. 127v) et ita approprianda huic ymagine signa adequate representativa clausularum istius hystorie etc. Deo gracias.

msItem.note: Fol. 128 is blank.

supportDesc.support: paper; fol. 86–120: steer’s head with flower, cf. Briquet no. 14760; fol. 121–8: two versions of steer’s head with flower, cf. Briquet 14785 (for general type), 14790

layoutDesc.layout: fol. 86–120: c. 36–40 long lines, not ruled, c. 175 120
fol. 121–8: frame ruling in ink, c. 30–4 long lines, c. 105 165

handDesc.handNote: In two 15th-cent. cursive hands (fols. 86–120, 121–8), the first part written in 1452 (fol. 105r)

decoDesc.decoNote: Diagrams deriving from Rámon Lull. (Pächt and Alexander i. 167)

msItem.title: Statutes and customs of the Cathedral Chapter of Bressanone (formerly Brixen), 20 March 1422
Record of the reading by the Dean, Nicolaus Swarat, to the Canons of Bressanone, of the Statuta et consuetudines dicti Capituli, and of their approval of them, 20 March 1422.
msItem.note: The names tally with those listed by F. A. Sinnacher, Beyträge zur Gesch. der bischöflichen Kirchen Sähen und Brixen in Tyrol VI, 1828, p. 88.

msItem.rubric: Tenores Statutorum et consuetudinum de quibus superius facta est mencio secuntur in hec verba
msItem.incipit: Quia kathedralium et aliarum ecclesiarum collegiatarum capitula facere possunt statuta licita et honesta
msItem.explicit: (fol. 137r) dictis hospitibus ipso facto privati.

msItem.title: Record of the approval and sealing of the statutes by the Bishop, Berchtholdus, and of the canons’ solemn oath to observe them
Testimony of the notary, Nicolaus Johannis Clericus Augustensis diocesis

msItem.note: The statutes have apparently been published by L. Santifaller, Gli statuti del capitolo della cattedrale di Bressanone nel medioevo, Archivio per l’Alto Adige 22, 1927; see J. Prader, Die Gerichtsbarkeit des Brixner Domkapitels in Festschrift zur Feier das 200 Jh. Bestandes des Haus-, Hof-, und Staatsarchivs (Vienna), 11, 1951, pp. 155, etc. Sinnacher, loc. cit., pp. 88–90, gives an account, of the Statutes Ex Autogr. in Arch. Capit. Some passages from the statutes are quoted by Santifaller, Das Brixner Domkapitel in seiner persönlichen Zusammensetzung in M.A. (Schlem-Schriften, 7), Innsbruck, 1924–5, pp. 105–6 (= our MS., fol. 130–131); 116 n. 63 (= fol. 134–134v; 233–4v–84 (= fol. 131–2), from Bressanone, Arch. Capit., Cod. L. 25 n. 3 fol. 3–14v. Prader, op. cit., p. 192 n. 4, quotes another passage (= fol. 135v).
Fol. 138v–140v are blank.

supportDesc.support: paper; watermarks, steer’s head with flower (two versions), cf. Briquet nos. 14751, 14760

layoutDesc.layout: partly with frame ruling in ink, c. 30–35 long lines, c. 170–80 110–20

handDesc.handNote: Written in the 15th cent, in a cursive hand

msItem.author: Elizabeth, dowager Queen of Hungary and Bohemia (?)
msItem.title: An exhortation to Frederick King of the Romans (elected 1440, cr. Emperor Frederick III in 1452) and his brother Albert (Albert VI Duke of Styria, d. 1463) to end their quarrel over their lands in Styria, Carinthia and Camiola
msItem.incipit: Prefulcite magister ac comprogenialis amantissime et dilecti Domini fratres nil aliud quam se totum licet in sudore vultus mei
msItem.explicit: (fol. 144r) in celo dignis coronabimur feliciter premiis adiuti per eum qui omnium bonorum amator est operum sempiternus etc.
msItem.note: On fol. 143v the writer says: Terminemus preterea vitam nostram exemplo domini regis Alberti pacifici confratruelis nostri nouiter heu defuncti … According to Du Cange, Glossarium ii, p. 502, confratruelis probably means a consort. King Albert II of Hungary and Bohemia died in October 1439; his queen, Elizabeth, daughter of the Emperor Sigismund and mother of Ladislas Postumus, died in December 1442.

msItem.author: Nicolaus Petschacher of Znoyma (Znaim)
msItem.title: Collection (anonymous in this MS.) of Latin poems chiefly about King Albert II of Hungary and Bohemia and the Hussite problem
msItem.incipit: Ecclesiam Christi quam pacificare cupivi.
msItem.note: Nos. XII, iª, xi 1. 1–14, v, xi, 1.15–18, x, vi, vii, viii, ix, ii, iii, iv of the collection ed. J. Huemer, Historische Gedichte aus dem XV Jh. Nicolaus Petschacher, M.I.Ö.G. 16 (1895), 638–47. He used Munich clm. 563, in which the poems are attributed to Petschacher, and our MS., then Admont 596, which he says (p. 638) has a better text, though fewer poems. Since our MS. does not include xiii, Epitaphium Elizabet regine, the poems in it may all have been written before her death in 1442.
Fol. 150–2 are blank.

supportDesc.support: paperl watermarks, scales, cf. Briquet no. 2401; mount in circle, cf. Briquet no. 11878

layoutDesc.layout: frame ruling in ink (apart from fol. 141r), c. 39 long lines, c. 165 90

handDesc.handNote: Written in the 15th cent, in a current fere hybrida

msItem.author: Johannes Bondi of Aquileia
msItem.title: Liber epythetorum
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber epythetorum compylatus a magistro Iohanne de Aquilegia in dictamine refulgent
msItem.incipit: Unus est pater omnium cuius nutu celestia et terrestria gubernantur
msItem.explicit: (fol. 160v) Et manifeste promittit fieri quod fit etc. Et sic est finis.
msItem.note: Rockinger, Briefsteller cit., p. 954 n. i, lists a libellus de epythetis by Bondi in Munich clm. 9683, fol. 13–16.

handDesc.handNote: written in the 15th cent, in a hybrid hand

msItem.title: Treatise on confession
msItem.incipit: Circa confessionem primo queritur ad quid sit utilis. Ad quod notandum quod confessio utilis est ad novem
msItem.explicit: (fol. 173ra) et licet non possit opera de genere bonorum mortua vivificare, potest tamen mortifica resuscitare. Amen dicant omnia. Amen.
msItem.colophon: Finivi librum scripsi sine manibus illum.
msItem.note: The treatise in MS. Trier Stadtbibi. 691, fol. 251–6, may be the same but its ending is different; see M. W. Bloomfield, Incipits, p. 275, no. 108.

msItem.incipit: Vidi alterum angelum ascendentem ab ortu solis… In hiis verbis honor et dingnitas exprimit
msItem.explicit: (fol. 174v) fructus honoris et honestatis. Istud singnum nullus defert nisi sit episcopus.

msItem.incipit: Et facta cena cum dyabolus iam misisset… Sic eciam Christus sciens quod debeat ab apostolis recedere prius voluit cum eis cenare
msItem.explicit: (fol. 175vb) veraciter et firmiter credere debent etc.

layoutDesc.layout: 160 105 : 2 cols, of 43 lines ruled in ink

handDesc.handNote: Written in the 13th–14th cent, in two current text hands: a. fol. 161–173v; b. fol. 173ra–175v.

msItem.title: Theological notes
msItem.note: chiefly on sin, penitence, and redemption, imperfect at beginning and end.
The first complete paragraph
msItem.incipit: (fol. 176rb) Nota quod legitur in Regum ubi Ieroboam egressus de Ierusalem magum invenit… (fol. 176rb) Nota sicut xii sunt hore diei.

msItem.note: The last paragraph
msItem.incipit: (fol. 183vb) Angeli eorum similiter vident faciem patris.

layoutDesc.layout: 144 100 : 2 cols, of 35 lines ruled in ink

handDesc.handNote: written in the 13th–14th cent, in a current text hand

msItem.author: Pope Paul II
msItem.title: Bulls against Georgy Podebrad, King of Bohemia, issued on 20 April 1468

msItem.incipit: Paulus episcopus servus servorum Dei, ad futuram rei memoriam. Licet inscrutabilis superni consilii prudencia
msItem.explicit: (fol. 185v) plenariam et liberam tenore presencium concedimus facultatem …
(fol. 186r) Datum Rome apud Sanctum Marcum anno incarnationis dominice Millesimo quadringentesimo sexagesimo octavo duodecima Kal. Maii, pontificatus nostri anno quarto etc.

msItem.incipit: Paulus episcopus servus servorum Dei, ad perpetuam rei memoriam. Regnans in secula sempiternus vivorum et mortuorum Iudex fortis et paciens
msItem.explicit: (fol. 188r) Et procul ab eis ecclesiastica sepultura eiciant corpora eorundem …
msItem.note: with the same date as 1.
Then follows the scribe’s colophon:
msItem.colophon: Ista copia collacionata et concordat cum originali scriptus per me Nicolaum Weigselpammer tunc temporis divinorum cooperator in valle Sell. Anno 1468º etc.
msItem.bibl: These Bulls are apparently printed in Scriptores Renan Silesicarum (or Sammlung schlesischer Geschichtsschreiber), ix, 1874, pp. 265–9; see Pastor, History of the Popes iv, 1894, p. 144. An extract from the first (= fol. 184’ 1. 10–185 1. 6) but dated xiii Kal. Maii, is printed by Raynaldus, Annales Ecclesiastici x, 1753, pp. 450–1.

msItem.note: Fol. 188v–192v are blank.

supportDesc.support: parchment; watermark, steer’s head with flower, cf. Briquet no. 14857

layoutDesc.layout: frame ruling in ink, c. 35–7 long lines, c. 175 110

handDesc.handNote: Written in 1468 in a current fere hybrida

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised from description by Albinia de la Mare.
